20110113170950.000|20110113170952.000|TR0|get access to her lungs, and it would be

20110113171022.000|20110113171024.000|TR0|opened her eyes.  (OFF- MIKE).
20110113171024.000|20110113171027.000|TR0|
20110113171027.000|20110113171029.000|TR0|LEMOLE:  I'll address that.
20110113171029.000|20110113171032.000|TR0|
20110113171032.000|20110113171034.000|TR0|So, when we examine patients, particularly 
20110113171034.000|20110113171037.000|TR0|in this state, we often have to wake them 
20110113171037.000|20110113171039.000|TR0|up, give them some stimulus.  And with 
20110113171039.000|20110113171042.000|TR0|that stimulus, they may crack their eyes.  
20110113171042.000|20110113171044.000|TR0|That's very different from speaking to 
20110113171044.000|20110113171046.000|TR0|someone and having them open their eyes, 
20110113171046.000|20110113171049.000|TR0|or having them open their eyes 
20110113171049.000|20110113171051.000|TR0|spontaneously in response to familiarity.
20110113171051.000|20110113171054.000|TR0|
20110113171054.000|20110113171056.000|TR0|QUESTION:  So the earlier eye-opening was 
20110113171056.000|20110113171059.000|TR0|more --
20110113171059.000|20110113171101.000|TR0|

20110113172208.000|20110113172210.000|TR0|So she'll have her ups and downs.  And so,

20110113172655.000|20110113172657.000|TR0|antibiotics for ear infections may not 
20110113172657.000|20110113172700.000|TR0|help immediately, but they do prevent

20110113172707.000|20110113172710.000|TR0|Our Senior Medical Correspondent Elizabeth 
20110113172710.000|20110113172712.000|TR0|Cohen is live in Miami to tell us more.
20110113172712.000|20110113172714.000|TR0|
20110113172714.000|20110113172717.000|TR0|Hi, Elizabeth.
20110113172717.000|20110113172719.000|TR0|
20110113172719.000|20110113172722.000|TR0|ELIZABETH COHEN, CNN SR. MEDICAL 
20110113172722.000|20110113172724.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Carol, I'm sure that most 
20110113172724.000|20110113172727.000|TR0|of the parents listening to this have 
20110113172727.000|20110113172729.000|TR0|brought their child into the pediatrician 
20110113172729.000|20110113172732.000|TR0|at some time or another for an ear 
20110113172732.000|20110113172734.000|TR0|infection. And what do parents expect when 
20110113172734.000|20110113172737.000|TR0|their child has an ear infection? They 
20110113172737.000|20110113172739.000|TR0|expect antibiotics.
20110113172739.000|20110113172741.000|TR0|
20110113172741.000|20110113172744.000|TR0|Well, "The New England Journal of 
20110113172744.000|20110113172746.000|TR0|Medicine" this week took a look at whether 
20110113172746.000|20110113172749.000|TR0|giving a child antibiotics really is the 
20110113172749.000|20110113172751.000|TR0|right approach. And they found some 
20110113172751.000|20110113172754.000|TR0|interesting results.
20110113172754.000|20110113172756.000|TR0|
20110113172756.000|20110113172759.000|TR0|Not surprisingly, they found that 
20110113172759.000|20110113172801.000|TR0|antibiotics do work, but not quite as well 
20110113172801.000|20110113172803.000|TR0|as you might think.  Let's take a look at 
20110113172803.000|20110113172806.000|TR0|the results of one of the studies.
20110113172806.000|20110113172808.000|TR0|
20110113172808.000|20110113172811.000|TR0|In this study, they found that when a 
20110113172811.000|20110113172813.000|TR0|child was given antibiotics for an ear 
20110113172813.000|20110113172816.000|TR0|infection, those symptoms went away after 
20110113172816.000|20110113172818.000|TR0|seven days 80 percent of the time.  When a 
20110113172818.000|20110113172821.000|TR0|child was given antibiotics, 80 percent of 
20110113172821.000|20110113172823.000|TR0|the time.  But when a child was given a 
20110113172823.000|20110113172826.000|TR0|placebo, which is a sugar pill that does 
20110113172826.000|20110113172828.000|TR0|nothing, the symptoms went away after 
20110113172828.000|20110113172830.000|TR0|seven days 74 percent of the time.
20110113172830.000|20110113172833.000|TR0|
20110113172833.000|20110113172835.000|TR0|So, as you can tell, that's not a huge 
20110113172835.000|20110113172838.000|TR0|difference.
20110113172838.000|20110113172840.000|TR0|
20110113172840.000|20110113172843.000|TR0|Now, seeing these results, a parent might 
20110113172843.000|20110113172845.000|TR0|say, well, the antibiotic did work better, 
20110113172845.000|20110113172848.000|TR0|so shouldn't I expect one when I bring my 
20110113172848.000|20110113172850.000|TR0|child in with an ear infection?  And the 
20110113172850.000|20110113172853.000|TR0|answer to that is maybe.
20110113172853.000|20110113172855.000|TR0|
20110113172855.000|20110113172857.000|TR0|Some pediatricians will tell you that if 
20110113172857.000|20110113172900.000|TR0|they see a child with a mild ear infection 
20110113172900.000|20110113172902.000|TR0|and no fever, or only a low fever, a child 
20110113172902.000|20110113172905.000|TR0|who otherwise is feeling pretty well can 
20110113172905.000|20110113172907.000|TR0|take Advil or Tylenol for the pain, they 
20110113172907.000|20110113172910.000|TR0|don't always give an antibiotic.  And the 
20110113172910.000|20110113172912.000|TR0|reason they feel that way is the 
20110113172912.000|20110113172915.000|TR0|antibiotics can actually sometimes make a 
20110113172915.000|20110113172917.000|TR0|child feel sick -- can give them diarrhea, 
20110113172917.000|20110113172919.000|TR0|or if they're little kids, can give them 
20110113172919.000|20110113172922.000|TR0|diaper rash.  And sometimes they prefer 
20110113172922.000|20110113172924.000|TR0|not to give one out at all.
20110113172924.000|20110113172927.000|TR0|
20110113172927.000|20110113172929.000|TR0|So what's an empowered patient supposed to 
20110113172929.000|20110113172932.000|TR0|do in this situation? In this situation,

20110113172934.000|20110113172937.000|TR0|for the ear infection, listen to your 
20110113172937.000|20110113172939.000|TR0|doctor and have a conversation.
20110113172939.000|20110113172942.000|TR0|
20110113172942.000|20110113172944.000|TR0|You can say, well, I really want them to 
20110113172944.000|20110113172946.000|TR0|have the antibiotic. You can hear their
